explanation: To determine whether mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_fallback_ participates in direct or indirect recursion you must inspect callers and any call chains that could lead back to it. The target has no callees, so any recursion would be via its caller mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count and that caller's callees (which might themselves call back). Therefore include:  - mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count: the direct caller; verify whether it (or functions it calls) can eventually call the target.  - mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_special_api_, mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_, mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_, mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count, mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_fallback_: all functions invoked by mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count; each must be inspected to see if they (directly or via further calls) call back to mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count or to the target.  - detect_cpu_core_count: the caller of mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count; include it to check higher-level call chains that could form a cycle.  Note: when analysing each listed symbol, also recursively inspect their callees (and any functions invoked via function pointers) to detect any cycle that returns to mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_fallback_.
